things.thing

Class Thing<V>

  • java.lang.Object
    • things.thing.Thing<V>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable, Comparable<Thing>

    public class Thing<V>
extends Object
implements Comparable<Thing>, Serializable

    A Thing is the central piece in this framework. In a nutshell, it wraps a value and makes it accessible via a type & key combination.

    The main elements of a Thing are:

    • id: id, unique across all Things
    • thingType: the type of the value (called ‘thingType’ instead of simply ‘type’ because ‘type’ seems to be a keyword way too often to not cause problems
    • key: the key that can be used to access this value. Keys don’t need to be unique, even among Things with the same type
    • value: the value that is wrapped by this Thing
    • parent: a list of ids that point to other things that this thing is a child of

    Properties of a Thing

    id

    When creating a Thing, you should not set an id, those are usually set by the underlying storage backend (ThingWriter).

    thingType

    The type of a Thing is linked to the implementing class of the @see Value it wrappes. You can use a TypeRegistry to convert between Type-strings, Type-classes and Value-types, there are also convenience methods to compare and inspect types. Further information in the ThingType javadoc.

    Types are needed for serializing and de-serializing values, both in a Thing-API and underlying storage engine.

    key

    Keys are used for look-ups. A Thing can have either:

    • a unique key for all Things of a certain type (indicated by the UniqueKey annotation), Things of a different type will still be able to use the same key
    • a unique key within all childs of a certain Type of a Thing (indicated by the UniqueKeyAsChild annotation), Things of a different type will still be able to use the same key
    • a key that is used by other Things of the same or other types
    value

    A value can implement any Java class (preferrably a POJO with id value though)

    Every storage backend (ThingWriter) can implement it’s own way of storing such a value. Normally a value would be stored and retrieved via an ‘id’ field. When looking up the value of Thing, always do via the ThingControlMinimal.getValue(Thing) method, because it is not guaranteed that the value is populated (lazy loading), so the getValue() method may return null.

    If the Value type is so that it only contains one String, it can be marked by the StringConverter attribute. If that is present, a ThingWriter can decide to serialize the value and, for example, store it directly as a property of a Thing, which might make querying more effective.

    parents

    Things can have links to other Things, which enables (simple) modelling of relationships. If a Thing can only be added to a certain Type of other Thing, you can specify that via the Subordinate annotation.

    See Also:

      • getId

        public String getId()

        Returns the id of this thing.

        Ids are created by the underlying storage backend and unique among all Things.

      • getKey

        public String getKey()

        Returns the key of this thing.

      • getParents

        public Set<String> getParents()

        Returns all the parent references of this thing

      • getThingType

        public String getThingType()

        Returns the type (see: ThingType) of this Things’ value.

      • getValue

        public V getValue()

        The value that is wrapped by this thing.

        Try to avoid getting it directly, instead use ThingControlMinimal.getValue(Thing) to make sure the value is populated by the associated ThingReader. If you can’t do that for some reason, make sure you check the getValueIsPopulated() method before retrieving the value.

      • getValueIsPopulated

        public Boolean getValueIsPopulated()

        Returns the state of this thing, i.e. whether the associated ThingReader did populate this Thing with the actual value (true) or whether lazy loading is used and the value is not populated (false).

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode()
        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object

      • setId

        public void setId(String id)

        Used internally for serialization/deserialization. Don’t use if you don’t know what you are doing.

        Parameters:
        id - the id

      • setKey

        public void setKey(String key)

        Sets the key of this thing.

        Usually you should not need to have to use this method.

        Parameters:
        key - the key

      • setParents

        public void setParents(Set<String> ids)

        Sets this Things parents.

        You should not need to use this method, if you want to add Things to Things to be stored on the storage backend use ThingControlMinimal.addChildThing(Thing, Thing).

        When returning Things via the API, parents are not included in the serialization, so don’t waste cycles adding Things in the first place.

        Parameters:
        ids - the list of ids that point to this Things’ other Things

      • setThingType

        public void setThingType(String type)

        Sets this Things’ type. Make sure you set a valid type (for example, check the TypeRegistry that is used in your application.

      • setValue

        public void setValue(V value)

        Sets the value of this Thing.

        It is preferrable to create a thing via ThingControl.createThing(String, Object), not doing it manually. If you use this method within a ThingReader/ThingWriter, make sure you also set the correct via setThingType(String) and also the populated state of this thing using setValueIsPopulated(Boolean).

        Parameters:
        value - the value

      • setValueIsPopulated

        public void setValueIsPopulated(Boolean valueIsPopulated)

        Sets whether this things value is the actual value (true), or whether it has to be loaded still (lazy loading - false).

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
